newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan mills foresee no sugar shortage.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan mills foresee no sugar shortage.

text.p: The Pakistan Sugar Mills Association said on Monday sugar stocks at mills would last until the next sugarcane crushing season starts in October.

"Sugar mills have enough sugar now," said one official of the association, responding to fears voiced by opposition leader Benazir Bhutto that Pakistan might soon face shortages of sugar and cooking oil following a recent unrest over a wheat crisis.
"The opposition always cries that a lion is coming out of the woods, but at the end we see a dog," one mill owner said.
A government spokesman, quoted by state television, said on Sunday that the government had decided to abolish a 10 percent import duty on sugar to forestall any shortages.
He said a formal announcement would be made after the cabinet's Economic Coordination Committee meets on Tuesday.
The PSMA official, who asked not to be named, said sugar production had reached 2.32 million tonnes by April 15 compared to 2.43 million tonnes at the same time a year ago.

He said mills aimed to produce 2.4 million tonnes in 1996/97, compared to 2.47 million in 1995/96 and 3.0 million in 1994/95. Dealers had bought 1.13 million tonnes, or 49 percent, of the production and 1.18 million remained at the mills.
He said that despite the comfortable stock position, some importers had opened at least 10 letters of credit to import 125,000 tonnes of sugar.
He could not say when it would arrive.
Cooking oil dealers said there were ample stocks of vegetable oils and domestic cottonseed oil would reach the market from July onwards as the cotton harvest arrives.
